title: SCDSS v. Padgett
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Deborah Padgett and John Doe, Defendants, 
Of whom Deborah Padgett is Appellant.
In the interest of: Michael Padgett, DOB 03/14/90, A child under the age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge
Â Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-312
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Allen W. Johnson, of Augusta, Georgia, for Appellant.
Dennis M. Gmerek, of Aiken, for Respondent.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Ziva Peleg Bruckner, of Columbia, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this appeal from a permanency planning order and from an order denying a motion[1] filed ten months after the merits removal hearing, Deborah Padgett (Mother) seeks to challenge the initial merits order which found she had physically abused and neglected her fourteen year-old-son, Michael.Â  Because we find that the Rule 59(e) motion was untimely and that Mother cannot appeal from the merits removal order by appealing from the subsequent permanency planning order, we affirm.[2]
FACTS
On October 4, 2004, the Aiken County Sheriff Department took Michael Padgett, a child under the age of eighteen, into emergency protective custody after Michael complained he had no place to stay nor anyone to care for him while Mother was in the hospital.Â  A hearing determined probable cause existed to remove Michael from Mother, and the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) assumed custody of Michael pending a merits hearing.Â  Mother was not present at the probable cause hearing.
The merits hearing was held on November 4, 2004.Â  When Mother failed to appear, DSS informed the court that she was personally served with the pleadings on October 6, 2004.Â  The court found: â€œThe defendant Deborah Padgett, was properly served with the summons, complaint, notice of right to counsel, and the date, time, and place of the hearing.â€Â  The court, after hearing testimony from the investigative caseworker, found Michael was an abused and/or neglected child pursuant to section 20-7-490 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 1997).Â  The court further found Mother physically abused Michael by her lack of supervision and her failure to make arrangements for his care while she was in the hospital.Â  There are also allegations of drug abuse on the part of Mother.[3]Â  Moreover, the court found removal to be in Michaelâ€™s best interest.Â  The order was signed on November 17, 2004. According to DSS, the order was â€œprovidedâ€ to Mother the next day; Mother does not dispute this finding.Â  Mother did not appeal from this order.Â  
On November 18, 2004, the day after the merits order was signed, Mother was appointed an attorney in this action.Â  Notice of the appointment was mailed to Motherâ€™s counsel on November 22, 2004.Â  On November 30, 2004, Mother, through her attorney, filed an answer to the complaint for removal even though the hearing on removal had already been conducted.Â  The answer did not raise any issues regarding service of the complaint on Mother or relating to her lack of representation at the removal hearing.
On September 22, 2005, the family court held a permanency planning hearing and approved a plan for an extension of time for reunification of Michael and Mother.Â  This order was entered on October 4, 2005, and mailed to Mother on October 11, 2005.Â  Prior to the September 22, 2005 permanency planning hearing, Mother filed a Rule 59(e) motion with the family court order for the removal order of November 17, 2004.Â  The motion was filed on September 15, 2005, nearly ten months after the removal order was signed.Â  In the Rule 59(e) motion, Mother raised, for the first time, issues regarding service of process and representation.Â  At the hearing, both DSS and the guardian opposed the motion as untimely, arguing over ten months had elapsed between entry of the removal order and the Rule 59(e) motion, and that no appeal had been timely filed from that order.Â  The family court denied the motion on November 14, 2005.Â  
Mother appeals from the family courtâ€™s permanency planning order of October 4, 2005, and the order denying the Rule 59 (e) motion on November 14, 2005.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When considering an appeal from the family court, appellate courts have the authority to find the facts in accordance with their view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  However, appellate courts defer to the family court judgeâ€™s determinations of witnessesâ€™ credibility because the family court judge had the opportunity to see and hear the witnesses testify.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
In her notice of appeal, Mother appeals from the October 4, 2005 family court order.Â  We find this appeal untimely.
Rule 203(b)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Appellate Practice (2006) governs appeals from the family courts and states: â€œA notice of appeal in a domestic relations action shall be served in the same manner provided by Rule 203(b)(1).â€Â  That section provides, â€œA notice of appeal shall be served on all respondents within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.â€Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  
In this matter, Mother did not file an appeal of the October 4, 2005 order until November 30, 2005, forty-eight days after the Rule 203(b)(1) requirement.Â  Therefore, the appeal of that order is untimely.
In her notice of appeal, Mother also appeals from the November 14, 2005 family court order denying her Rule 59(e) motion of the November 17, 2004 removal order.Â  In the Rule 59(e) motion dated September 15, 2005, Mother raised, for the first time, issues regarding service of process of the complaint and her lack of representation at the merits removal hearing.Â  We find her Rule 59(e) motion was not timely filed with the family court.Â  
Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides that â€œ[a] motion to alter or amend the judgment shall be served not later than 10 days after receipt of written notice of the entry of the order.â€Â  This motion was filed some ten months after the order was entered on November 17, 2004, and provided to her the following day.Â  Therefore, the family court correctly denied the motion.Â  See also Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 563 S.E.2d 193 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding courts retain jurisdiction to alter judgments for ten days if a motion to alter or amend a judgment is filed; however, after ten days that jurisdiction is lost).
Moreover, Mother includes in her statement of issues on appeal arguments relating to service of process and her lack of appointed counsel at the merits hearing.Â  However, the first argument in the brief is captioned: â€œEveryone is entitled to due process and â€˜the resistance to tyranny is obedience to God.â€™ Thomas Jefferson.â€Â  This section does not address either issue set out in the statement of issues on appeal.Â  It appears to be nothing but a recitation of the facts of the case.Â  Moreover, Mother failed to provide arguments or supporting authority for this assertion.Â  Thus, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal. Â See e.g., First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting where a party fails to cite authority or where the argument is simply a conclusory statement, the party is deemed to have abandoned the issue).
The second argument in the brief combines the service of process issue and the representation issue into one argument.Â  Mother contends she was not properly served with the summons and complaint for the removal hearing, and that she was not represented at the removal hearing as required by section 20-7-110(B) of the South Carolina Code (2004).Â  We hold Mother waived those arguments.
A party waives improper service as a defense by failing to raise the issue in his answer.Â  Rule 12(h), SCRCP; Garner v. Houck, 312 S.C. 481, 487, 435 S.E.2d 847, 850 (1993).Â  Here, Motherâ€™s answer, filed on November 30, 2004, was silent on the issue of service of process and her lack of representation at the merits hearing.Â  It was not until her untimely Rule 59(e) motion, filed on September 15, 2005, that Mother formally raised this issue.Â Â  Mother simply cannot fail to raise an issue in a responsive pleading filed with the family court, and then seek to raise those issues via a Rule 59(e) motion filed ten months after issuance of the merits order.Â  
Additionally, Motherâ€™s attorney did not raise the issue of her lack of representation until her untimely Rule 59(e) motion.Â  While we are mindful that Motherâ€™s attorney was not appointed to represent her until after the merits hearing had concluded, counselâ€™s failure to raise this issue in a timely fashion bars mother from arguing this issue on appeal.Â  See Clark v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 608 S.E.2d 573 (2005) (holding an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the orders of the family court are
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] This motion was captioned â€œmotion for rehearingâ€ by Motherâ€™s counsel.Â  Both the family court and DSS characterized the motion as a Rule 59(e) motion; however, the motion itself does not reference any of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  There is no indication in the argument before the family court that this motion should be construed as a Rule 60 motion to re-open the judgment.
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] It should be noted that in the July 14, 2005 review hearing the family court found Mother was recently hospitalized for trying to commit suicide by overdosing on her diabetes medicine.Â  Additionally, she had previously been incarcerated for intent to possess crack cocaine.Â

title: Uzenda v. Pittman
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda, Appellant,
v.
Nancy and Michael Pittman, Christopher Hanna, Perry P. Reynolds and Scott
Gobbi, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.2006-UP-313
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 20, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda, of Myrtle Beach, pro se.
Natasha M. Hanna, of Myrtle Beach for Respondent Christopher Hanna; and Russell V. Traw, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents Nancy and Michael Pittman.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this action by Jara Uzenda[1] for breach of trust with fraudulent intent, fraudulent conveyance, conspiracy, intentional infliction of emotional distress, unjust enrichment, and breach of contract, the circuit court granted summary judgment to Christopher Hanna and Nancy and Michael
  Pittman, and granted motions to dismiss as to both Scott Gobbi and Perry P. Reynolds.Â  Uzenda appeals.Â  We affirm. [2]  
FACTS
In December 1999, Gobbi signed an exclusive right to sell agreement with Realty One for the sale of property he owned at 407 Chesterfield Court.Â  On January 7, 2000, Uzenda and Gobbi signed a contract (the Contract) to sell Unit 67 at 407 Chesterfield Court (the Property) to the Pittmans, with closing to occur on January 28, 2000.Â  The Pittmans agreed to pay $83,400 for the Property.Â  In addition, Uzenda signed a disclosure form consenting to Hanna, a real estate agent for Realty One, acting as a dual agent in the transaction.Â  Reynolds subsequently appraised the Property at $83,500.Â  
On January 28, 2000, Uzenda informed Gobbi, the Pittmans, and Hanna that she would not close on the Property for a variety of reasons, including past flooding problems and an existing lawsuit. Â On the same date, the Pittmans signed an addendum to the Contract acknowledging they were made aware of these problems.Â  Furthermore, Gobbi entered into an agreement giving the Pittmans permission to occupy the Property rent-free beginning on January 28, 2000.[3]Â  
In June, in an action separate from the present one, Gobbi sought and obtained an order of the family court requiring Uzenda to convey the Property to the Pittmans.Â  In August, Uzenda was held in contempt of this order, and subsequently conveyed the Property as a gift to Gobbi.Â  In the meantime, the Pittmans found another property to purchase and eventually vacated the Property.Â  A mortgage holder subsequently foreclosed on the Property, and the Property was sold in a foreclosure sale.Â  
In November, Uzenda filed a complaint in circuit court against the Pittmans, Hanna, Gobbi, and Reynolds alleging breach of trust with fraudulent intent, fraudulent conveyance, conspiracy, intentional infliction of emotional distress, unjust enrichment, and breach of contract.Â  In February 2001, Uzenda made a written motion to join her action in magistrateâ€™s court against the Pittmans with the current action.Â  
The Honorable Judge James E. Brogdon, Jr. granted summary judgment to Hanna on October 26, 2001.Â  Uzenda filed a motion to alter or amend this order.Â  In December, Judge Brogdon denied Uzendaâ€™s motion to alter or amend, and Uzenda filed a second motion to alter or amend. Â Judge Brogdon also denied this motion.Â  Also in December, Judge Brogdon granted the motions to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(5) and (6), SCRCP, of both Gobbi and Reynolds.Â  
In July 2003, Uzenda and the Pittmans exchanged discovery requests.Â  On August 26, 2003, the Pittmans served Uzenda with a motion for summary judgment.Â  In January 2004, Uzenda made a written motion to postpone the hearing of the pending motions in front of Judge Edward B. Cottingham because, she alleged, a motion to reconsider was outstanding in front of Judge Brogdon.Â  Judge Cottingham held a hearing and granted Uzendaâ€™s motion, believing her allegation to be true. Judge Cottingham subsequently determined that he did in fact have jurisdiction over the matter and a new hearing was scheduled.Â  At the outset of the hearing, Uzenda moved to have the current case consolidated with the pending magistrateâ€™s action, which Uzenda alleged was on appeal to the circuit court after a ruling in favor of the Pittmans.Â  Judge Cottingham denied the motion.Â  On February 4, 2004, Judge Cottingham granted summary judgment to the Pittmans.Â  Uzenda filed a motion for reconsideration of this order, which Judge Cottingham denied.Â  Â Â This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Jurisdiction
Uzenda argues Rule 43(l), SCRCP, prevented Judge Cottingham from ruling on a matter in a case in which Judge Brogdon heard motions.Â  We disagree.
Rule 43(l), SCRCP, provides: Â â€œ[i]f any motion be made to any judge and be denied, in whole or in part, or be granted conditionally, no subsequent motion upon the same state of facts shall be made to any other judge in that action.â€Â  In this case, Judge Cottingham did not hear or decide any motion that was denied or conditionally granted by Judge Brogdon.Â  Therefore, Rule 43(l) did not preclude Judge Cottingham from ruling on all motions before him.
II. Magistrateâ€™s court action
Uzenda argues the trial court did not have jurisdiction to hear the Pittmanâ€™s motion for summary judgment because her claims for ejectment and back rent had been decided by the magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Uzenda did not provide a sufficient record on appeal for this court to determine whether any issue ruled upon by the trial court was heard before the magistrate.Â  See Hamilton v. Greyhound Lines E., 281 S.C. 442, 444, 316 S.E.2d 368, 369 (1984) (â€œThe appealing party has the burden of furnishing a sufficient record from which this court can make an intelligent review.â€).Â  
Uzenda also argues the trial court erred in failing to consolidate the present action with an appeal from the magistrateâ€™s court involving the Pittmans.Â  Specifically, Uzenda argues the trial court should consolidate these actions under Rule 18(b), SCRCP. Â We disagree.
â€œConsolidation is within the broad discretion of the trial court.Â  The moving party has the burden of persuading the court that consolidation is desirable. Â An appellate court will not disturb a trial courtâ€™s ruling on a motion to consolidate absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Keels v. Pierce, 315 S.C. 339, 342, 433 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 1993) (internal citations omitted).
Rule 18(b) provides:

Whenever a claim is one heretofore cognizable only after another claim has been prosecuted to a conclusion, the two claims may be joined in a single action; but the court shall grant relief in that action only in accordance with the relative substantive rights of the parties. In particular, a plaintiff may state a claim for money and a claim to have set aside a conveyance fraudulent as to him, without first having obtained a judgment establishing the claim for money.

In this case, Uzenda sets forth no reason why her present claim is cognizable only after her appeal from magistrateâ€™s court is prosecuted to its conclusion.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying Uzendaâ€™s motion to consolidate.
III. Summary Judgment for Hanna and the Pittmans
Uzenda argues the trial court erred in granting Hanna and the Pittmansâ€™ motions for summary judgment.Â  We disagree.Â  
A. Notice of Summary Judgment
Initially, Uzenda argues she did not have sufficient notice of summary judgment as to either Hanna or the Pittmans.Â  We hold Uzenda received proper notice of summary judgment as to both Hanna and the Pittmans.Â  â€œIf, on a motion . . . to dismiss for failure of the pleading to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, matters outside the pleading are presented to and not excluded by the Court, the motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as provided in Rule 56, and all parties shall be given reasonable opportunity to present all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.â€Â  Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP, provides a motion for summary judgment must be served at least ten days prior to the time fixed for the hearing.Â  
Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, â€œspecifically provides for conversion, provided the parties, upon compliance with the notice provisions of Rule 56, are afforded a reasonable opportunity to introduce evidentiary matters.â€Â  Johnson v.
